title: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of REM sleep behavior disorder in adults. Covers idiopathic/isolated RBD and symptomatic RBD associated with synucleinopathies. Includes diagnostic workup, safety interventions, pharmacologic treatment, and longitudinal monitoring for phenoconversion to Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, or multiple system atrophy. Excludes other parasomnias as separate entities, though differential diagnosis is addressed.

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Exclude anemia or infection contributing to sleep disturbance
Exclude thyroid dysfunction contributing to sleep disturbance
B12 deficiency can cause neuropsychiatric symptoms and sleep disruption
Iron deficiency contributes to RLS/PLMD which may coexist with or mimic RBD
Assess iron status; low iron saturation associated with sleep movement disorders
Exclude substance use contributing to parasomnia; required before PSG

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Screen for autoimmune conditions associated with secondary RBD
Inflammatory markers; screen for systemic autoimmune or inflammatory conditions
Exclude neurosyphilis as a cause of CNS-related sleep disturbance
HIV can cause CNS dysfunction and secondary sleep disorders
Autoimmune/paraneoplastic etiologies can cause secondary RBD; anti-IgLON5 disease particularly associated with RBD and NREM parasomnia

Essential/First-line.timing: Gold standard diagnostic study; expanded montage includes bilateral flexor digitorum superficialis, bilateral anterior tibialis, and bilateral extensor digitorum brevis

Essential/First-line.target: Irregular sleep patterns; document nocturnal movement episodes

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: Rule out structural brain lesions (brainstem, hypothalamic); assess for synucleinopathy markers (nigrostriatal degeneration)
Extended.target: Exclude structural lesion; document brainstem integrity; nigrostriatal changes may suggest early PD/MSA

Extended.timing: Assess nigrostriatal dopaminergic integrity; reduced uptake suggests prodromal PD/DLB; most useful when new motor symptoms emerge
Extended.target: Reduced striatal dopamine transporter uptake (abnormal = prodromal synucleinopathy); normal does not exclude future conversion

Rare/Specialized.timing: Assess cardiac sympathetic denervation; reduced uptake in PD/DLB but preserved in MSA; helps differentiate synucleinopathy subtypes
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced heart-to-mediastinum ratio suggests PD or DLB; preserved ratio may suggest MSA
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Concurrent medications that affect norepinephrine uptake (labetalol, TCAs); uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmias

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Prevent injury from dream enactment behavior; first-line for all RBD patients

dosing.instructions: Lower bed to floor level or use mattress on floor; remove nightstands with sharp corners; pad bedside furniture; remove potentially dangerous objects (lamps, glasses, weapons) from bedroom; install bed rails with padding; consider sleeping bag to limit limb movement

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Protect bed partner from injury during violent dream enactment

dosing.instructions: Consider separate sleeping arrangements if violent behaviors persist despite pharmacotherapy; bed partner should sleep in separate bed or room until behaviors controlled; communicate safety plan to household

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.monitoring: Bed partner injury reports; relationship assessment

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Reduce injury risk from falling out of bed

dosing.instructions: Place thick padding, mattress, or cushions on floor adjacent to all sides of bed; ensure no hard objects near bed perimeter

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Prevent serious injury from complex dream enactment behaviors

dosing.instructions: Lock windows; move bed away from windows; secure heavy or breakable objects in bedroom; remove firearms from bedroom; consider door alarm if sleepwalking component present

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.indication: First-line pharmacotherapy for RBD; preferred due to excellent safety profile and minimal side effects; restores REM atonia

dosing.instructions: Start 3 mg 30-60 minutes before bedtime; titrate by 3 mg every 1-2 weeks as needed; effective range 3-12 mg/day; max 12 mg/day; may take 2-4 weeks for full effect; preferred in elderly and patients with OSA or cognitive impairment

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.monitoring: Daytime sedation; headache; vivid dreams; next-day grogginess at higher doses

Referrals & Consults.item: Sleep medicine specialist for video-PSG with expanded EMG montage, diagnosis confirmation, and pharmacotherapy optimization (gold standard diagnosis requires in-lab PSG)

Neurology/movement disorder specialist for longitudinal phenoconversion monitoring; annual assessment for emerging parkinsonism, cognitive decline, or autonomic dysfunction is essential given >90% lifetime conversion risk
Neuropsychology for baseline cognitive testing (MoCA and detailed neuropsychological battery) and serial monitoring if cognitive concerns emerge; cognitive decline may herald phenoconversion to DLB

Psychiatry if discontinuation of RBD-triggering antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs) is being considered; ensure safe transition to non-RBD-triggering alternatives (bupropion, trazodone) without psychiatric decompensation
Physical/occupational therapy for fall risk assessment and home safety evaluation; particularly important if early motor features of parkinsonism emerge
Otolaryngology or pulmonology if concurrent obstructive sleep apnea identified on PSG, as untreated OSA can exacerbate RBD and clonazepam is contraindicated in severe OSA

Patient/Family Instructions.item: RBD is a sleep disorder where normal muscle paralysis during dreaming sleep is absent, causing you to physically act out dreams; this is a neurological condition, not a behavioral or psychological problem

Bedroom safety is the most important intervention: lower bed to floor, remove sharp/dangerous objects, pad furniture, lock windows, and consider separate sleeping if violent behaviors put a bed partner at risk
Do not attempt to restrain or wake someone during an RBD episode as this may worsen agitation; instead, move to a safe distance and ensure the environment is clear of hazards
Take melatonin or clonazepam exactly as prescribed 30-60 minutes before bedtime; do not abruptly stop clonazepam as this may cause withdrawal symptoms and rebound RBD
Avoid alcohol and caffeine in the evening as these can worsen RBD symptoms and disrupt sleep architecture

Report any new symptoms to your neurologist immediately: tremor, slowness of movement, balance problems, memory changes, constipation, loss of smell, or lightheadedness upon standing (these may signal conversion to a related neurological condition)
Inform all healthcare providers about RBD diagnosis; certain medications (SSRIs, SNRIs, beta-blockers, tramadol) can trigger or worsen RBD and should be avoided when alternatives exist
Keep a sleep diary documenting frequency and severity of dream enactment episodes, injuries, and medication effects to guide treatment adjustments

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain regular sleep-wake schedule with consistent bedtime and wake time to promote consolidated sleep and reduce RBD episode frequency
Regular moderate exercise (30 minutes daily) to improve sleep quality and potentially slow neurodegenerative progression; avoid vigorous exercise within 3 hours of bedtime
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs; alcohol disrupts REM sleep architecture and may exacerbate dream enactment behaviors
Limit caffeine intake, especially after noon, as caffeine disrupts sleep continuity and may increase nocturnal arousals

Avoid known RBD-triggering medications whenever possible: SSRIs (fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine, citalopram), SNRIs (venlafaxine, duloxetine), beta-blockers, and tramadol; discuss alternatives with prescribing physicians
Stress reduction and relaxation techniques before bedtime (meditation, deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation) may reduce episode frequency
Maintain healthy body weight and manage cardiovascular risk factors; metabolic health may influence neurodegenerative risk
Engage in cognitively stimulating activities (reading, puzzles, social interaction) to promote cognitive reserve

differential.features: Occur during deep NREM sleep (first third of night); typically eyes open, ambulate, less violent; confused upon awakening with amnesia for event; more common in children; no REM without atonia on PSG
differential.tests: Video-PSG showing events arise from NREM (N3) sleep; no RSWA; age of onset typically childhood

differential.features: Stereotyped motor behaviors; may have tonic or hyperkinetic movements; brief episodes (<2 min); can occur multiple times per night from NREM sleep; may respond to antiseizure medications
differential.tests: Video-EEG with expanded montage; stereotyped pattern; events from NREM; may see epileptiform discharges

differential.features: Abnormal behaviors triggered by respiratory arousals from OSA; may mimic dream enactment; resolves with CPAP treatment; AHI >5 on PSG
differential.tests: PSG with respiratory scoring; behaviors coincide with apneic events; resolution with CPAP; no true RSWA

differential.features: Vivid trauma-related nightmares with motor activity and vocalizations; history of psychological trauma; REM without atonia typically absent on PSG; responds to trauma-focused therapy
differential.tests: Clinical history of trauma; PSG typically shows normal REM atonia; psychiatric evaluation; PTSD screening (PCL-5)

differential.features: Sudden awakening with intense fear, palpitations, dyspnea, diaphoresis; typically from NREM sleep; no violent motor behavior or dream enactment; fully alert upon awakening
differential.tests: PSG shows events from NREM; no RSWA; psychiatric evaluation; history of daytime panic disorder

differential.features: Complex behaviors during apparent sleep with variable pattern; eyes open; prolonged episodes (minutes to hours); associated with history of abuse or dissociative disorder; EEG shows wakefulness
differential.tests: Video-PSG shows episodes arise from wakefulness (EEG wake pattern); psychiatric evaluation; history of dissociation

differential.features: RBD symptoms temporally related to initiation of SSRIs, SNRIs, beta-blockers, or tramadol; may resolve with medication discontinuation
differential.tests: Medication timeline correlation; PSG before and after medication change; symptom resolution with drug withdrawal

differential.features: Generalized tonic-clonic or complex partial seizures during sleep; postictal confusion, tongue biting, incontinence; stereotyped events; may have daytime seizures
differential.tests: Video-EEG monitoring; postictal state; stereotyped semiology; epileptiform discharges

differential.features: Repetitive stereotyped limb movements during NREM sleep; no dream enactment or vocalizations; may cause arousals and daytime sleepiness
differential.tests: PSG shows PLMS >15/hour during NREM; no RSWA; no complex behaviors

evidence.recommendation: ICSD-3-TR diagnostic criteria for RBD require video-PSG demonstrating REM without atonia and dream enactment behavior
Isolated RBD is the strongest prodromal marker of synucleinopathies with >90% lifetime phenoconversion risk to PD, DLB, or MSA
RBD strongly associated with future development of PD and DLB; phenoconversion biomarkers include DaT scan, olfactory testing, and cognitive assessment
Melatonin effective for RBD with favorable safety profile; preferred first-line in elderly and patients with OSA
Clonazepam effective in 80-90% of RBD patients; use limited by sedation, fall risk, and OSA exacerbation
evidence.source: [Aurora et al. J Clin Sleep Med 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20572421/)

evidence.recommendation: AASM Best Practice Guide recommends clonazepam and melatonin as first-line pharmacotherapy for RBD
evidence.source: [Aurora et al. J Clin Sleep Med 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20572421/)

evidence.recommendation: DaT scan, cardiac MIBG, olfactory testing, and cognitive assessment serve as biomarkers for prodromal synucleinopathy in iRBD
SSRIs and SNRIs can trigger or exacerbate RBD; medication review and substitution recommended
Alpha-synuclein seed amplification assay in CSF shows high sensitivity and specificity for prodromal synucleinopathy in iRBD patients
Video-PSG with expanded EMG montage (SINBAR method) is the gold standard for RSWA quantification and RBD diagnosis
Environmental safety measures and bedroom modifications are first-line non-pharmacologic interventions for all RBD patients
Phenoconversion risk stratification using multimodal biomarkers (DaT, olfaction, cognition, autonomic function) enables early identification of neurodegenerative trajectory

DaT scan; movement disorder referral; consider dopaminergic therapy

Document; autonomic dysfunction may herald synucleinopathy; manage symptomatically
Reduce clonazepam dose; switch to melatonin; evaluate for concurrent sleep disorder

monitoring.action: Reduce clonazepam; physical therapy referral; home safety evaluation

monitoring.frequency: At initiation and with dose changes

disposition.criteria: Majority of patients; newly suspected or established RBD for diagnostic workup, treatment initiation, and longitudinal phenoconversion monitoring
Patients requiring in-lab video-polysomnography with expanded EMG montage for definitive diagnosis; overnight monitored study

Significant injury from dream enactment behavior requiring medical evaluation (fractures, head trauma, lacerations); concurrent acute neurological presentation requiring inpatient workup (new parkinsonism, acute cognitive decline, suspected autoimmune encephalitis with RBD)
Acute injury from RBD episode (bed partner assault, fall with head trauma, fractures); initiate safety counseling and urgent sleep medicine referral
Rarely indicated for RBD alone; consider if severe traumatic injury from dream enactment (subdural hematoma, cervical spine injury) or if respiratory depression from clonazepam overdose
All patients with suspected RBD for video-PSG diagnosis and treatment management
All patients with confirmed iRBD for longitudinal phenoconversion surveillance; urgent if new motor, cognitive, or autonomic symptoms emerge
Every 2-4 weeks during initial treatment titration; every 6 months once stable; annually for comprehensive phenoconversion screening (cognitive, motor, olfactory, autonomic)
